utterances: Thank you.
And Sarah Dunant, we wish you a lot of sleep, you're about to start a ten-city tour?
Yes, I'm going to be a doormouse when I'm not talking.

Thank you, Neal.
Sarah Dunant is the author, most recently, of In the Company of the Courtesan.
She joined us here in Studio 3-A.
I'm Neal Conan, NPR News, in Washington.
Elections can be humbling.
For a day, all the experts in pols have to hold their breath until millions of people who sell shoes, clean streets or park cars have had their say.
Voters can bedevil experts by expressing what seem to be opposing views.
We went into north central New Jersey this week to try to hear what's on the minds of people as they prepare to vote, or not.
We found people who supported the war in Iraq but want to bring the soldiers home now.
We met people opposed to the war who worry about bringing the soldiers back too quickly.
We met immigrants irritated by illegal immigration and people who worry about global warming, but want to drill in the Alaska Wildlife Refuge to bring down the cost of gas.
There was a group of men at lunch at the Jersey Boys Bagel Shop in Morristown, where they offer a grilled American cheese on white bread called the Bruce Springsteen Special.
Ken said he cares most about...
The price of gasoline, the war in Iraq, and the fact that my homeowner's insurance in Florida has gone up like double in the past year.
You said the war in Iraq.
What are your concerns about that?
It's gone on too long and it seems to be going in the wrong direction.
Did you accept or support the war three years ago?
Yes, I did.
And maybe my views are starting to change a little bit.
His friend Craig also supported the war.
Oh, definitely.
Yes, definitely.
I still do support every last one of them that are fighting.
Thirty-one-year-old Roy Ramirez says it's tough filling up his beat up '57 Chevy taxi.
OK.
Well, Chelsea, thanks very much for the call.
Thanks.
All right, and I think she would probably fall into the category of the people who really, really, really enjoy camp.
Well, no, actually, I - maybe I heard it wrong, but it seemed to me that she just enjoyed camp.
OK.
And those people, I conclude in my analysis, are normal people.
So, I don't place much importance in the fact that she could live close to her parents, she could live far away from her parents.
You know, I think these are people who - about whom you can't draw too many conclusions.
They tend to have the lightest psychotherapy bills, I think, of any group that we're discussing here today.
Unlikely to bite their dogs.
(Soundbite of laughter)
This is, I do maintain, this is the most reliable Rorschach that exists of people's basic character.
Well, what are those people who really, really, really, really, really liked it?
You call them camp cultists.
The camp cultist, yes.
Well, before we get to them, we have the people who just really, really enjoy camp, and these people, I think, are a little unbalanced.
There is a difference between enjoying camp and really, really enjoying camp.
These are the people who weep at the final campfire of the year uncontrollably.

And I think these people tend to end up in abusive relationships with angry men, if they're women - and they are usually women - and if they're men, you might see them now and then speeding away from a grade-school playground in the back of a police cruiser.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Then you move on to the people who are really, really, really lovers of camp, and you would think, given the direction of my analysis, that this would mean that these people are off-the-chart crazy.

In fact - and I call them the camp cultists - in fact, you reach a point where the people love camp so much that they actually jump to a positive category, which is, these people, these camp cultists, are the leaders of our country.
These people grow up to be chief executive officers of major corporations, named partners in Wall Street banking firms, Cabinet secretaries, governors, presidents of prestigious foundations.
Universities invite them to serve on their boards.
These people are the American establishment.
For example, longtime Disney CEO Michael Eisner loved his camp so much he wrote a book about it, and he dedicated much of his life, his adult life, to making sure that this camp survived.
Weird?
Yes, but I think we can't dispute that Michael Eisner is a very successful person.
You know, camp cultists have a lifetime relationship with their camps.
When they are done being campers, they become counselors.
When they're too old to be counselors, they send their kids.
Their kids invariably figure out a way to get thrown out of camp.
When that happens, they just send lots of money.
So, I think the lesson here is, if you're going to love camp, you really want to love it off the charts, and then you'll be a successful person.
If you just love it a whole lot, then you're just going to be weird.
Let's get Judy on the line, Judy with us from Holland, Michigan.
Hello.
Thank you for taking my call.
Go ahead, please.
I went to camp, oh, when I was 9 or 10, and what I remember about it, and disliking it, was the basicness (ph) of the arrangements.
The accommodations.
Yes.

And that would have been a waste of money.
Yes.
Did she stick it out?
You know, this was 1948, maybe, and I can't remember.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, she's probably all right, then.
Yes, she's probably all right.
OK, Judy.
Thanks very much for the call.
Bye-bye.
Bye-bye.

Hi.
